Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Interactive Multi-Touch Collaborative Table for Classrooms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Templeman Automation (TA) and Tufts Center for Engineering Education and Outreach (CEEO), propose using TA's open-architecture touch-table for STEM educational applications. The ?STEM-Table? applies multi-touch computing to collaborative learning, project-based engineering education, individual-within-group skills assessment, and across-sciences visualization and augmented reality. These applications will leverage students? natural fascination towards touch interfaces and direct them through STEM educational goals using multi-touch-specific curriculum modules. With the benefit of SBIR funding, a multi-touch toolset and activities/curriculum will be developed that are designed within the multi-touch table environment to provide augmented science activities for STEM education.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that STEM-Table (1) brings high-end interactive experiences to diverse classrooms; (2) enables out-of-the-box (engineering) and end-result (instruction) science learning; and (3) will provide a new paradigm for collaborative STEM activities while providing teacher workload reduction and targeted skills assessment.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research lies in the melding of the multi-touch table environment with the educational experience of the CEEO. Working together, a new model of classroom interaction will be created to provide the access, supports, and scaffolds that students need to make sense of science and become excited by STEM's creative opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STEM Table is a large-format touch table for classroom math and science education.  It is similar to a huge iPad that multiple students gather around. Specially-engineered devices or "Smart Objects" can be manipulated on the display surface to allow students to interact with educational applications.

Imagine a group of students around our table. It guides them to collide two real, physical pucks together on the surface. If they hit "start" and slide the pucks, the path of the puck is tracked and displayed.

  • Plus at the collision point the vectors are superimposed to illustrate conservation of momentum
  • Plus they can open up a control panel for the puck and change its coefficient of friction and see information about it
  • Plus by touching the path they can open up plots of the displacement vs time and overlay velocity vs time and acceleration vs time and drill down to the raw data


So, the table augments reality of a teaching lab experiment and allows students to explore the equipment, graphical control panels, real-time data being generated, and multimedia analysis of what is going on. It is a powerful and fun learning tool.

Several educational ideas have been tested using the STEM Table platform as part of TA's NSF-funded Phase I SBIR program. Activities were prototyped across the following STEM fields: (1) In physics, interaction of the table with both rolling objects and pendulums to explore fundamental laws of motion; (2) In chemistry, experiments for assisting with accurate chemical measurements and visualization of molecular composition; (3) In biology, explorations into the human body, providing an opportunity for student-led, hands-on inquiry of the muscle, organ, and bone layers beneath the skin; (4) In math, a collaboration with Fluidity Software to provide solutions for arithmetic and more advanced graphing functions; (5) In engineering, both small robots that interact with the table and exploration of a fluid-dynamics simulator; (6) In early learning, a collaborative art program that can be used with younger, elementary-aged students. This work will be extended in Phase II.

Broadly, the goal of STEM Table is to address the downward trend in American STEM education, and its corresponding negative implications for America's future economy, security, and competitiveness. In the Phase I work, TA and its collaborators devised and tested a prototype augmented-reality laboratory bench, intended to foster a culture of enthusiasm regarding STEM from the earliest ages. Just as STEM disciplines often require teamwork and collaborative thinking, STEM Table enables group exploration in a way that is engaging, immersive, and supportable in a classroom setting.
